narratives.question_text:
What knowledge, skills, and insights did you develop by taking this course?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: I learned basic concepts in the field of linguistics, including the structure of language, language acquisition, and the implications of the former for gaining insights into how the mind works.

I learned the fundamentals of semantics, syntax, phonology, and morphology. I learned to how apply the methods of linguistics to real questions in the field. I learned how language impacts society through heritage speakers and language acquisition. I learned how to conduct a survey-based experiment from its conception to a final report.

This is an amazing course. I learned so much about the intersection between language and cognition. The class was framed in a way in which it used the lexical item to lead all future discussion about how language related to the mind.
I learned so much about linguistics and how language relates to the mind, something of interest to me as a psych major.

I learned about a mind/brain approach to linguistics and learned a lot about neuroscience/cogsci/linguistics in the process. The last third was more about these topics and was really fun. I also learned how conduct my own linguistic research project and collect data for myself, which was my first experience doing somethijng like that. I had a lot of fun with that project.

I learned the basics of linguistics, of course. But more importantly, I got a taste of how incredible and complex our minds are through the lense of langauge. This is something that, I hope, will never leave me.
I learned more about the components of language, like phonetics and what makes up a lexical item, and where language resides.

narratives.question_text:
What are the strengths and weaknesses of this course and how could it be improved?
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: The quizzes and assignments were extremely reasonable and really helped to put what we learned into practice. We received handouts after every class that consolidated each unit and helped me to focus on the main points.

The course material is perfectly balanced between learning about the language system and learning about the implications of that system. The class sessions consist of open-ended discussions, which helped me stay engaged and were a nice departure from the typical Yale lecture course. The one area for improvement is that it would have been helpful to have a class session devoted to research methods the final project (e.g. how to present linguistic materials to participants, good scientific practices like having a control group).

Strengths are the professor and the TA. The class was taught well, the readings were very interesting, and the quizzes were very similar to the homework. I never felt underprepared in the course, and Professor Pinango was very upfront on the material she would be teaching and how to present it. 
Not many weaknesses. The homework are sometimes very confusing, but they ended up being graded pretty fairly even if the material wasn't covered.
A lot of material is thoroughly discussed in the class, but not before the homework is due. It is difficult to know if you are fully understanding the material before you have to submit the homework.

I liked the small lecture/seminar format of the class and how much we were encouraged to ask questions. It felt like we got off topic sometimes, but this was manageable. The homework assignments were great practice, but some were longer than they needed to be in my opinion.

This course is very interesting, and the material is taught well. Professor Piango and Mr. Geissler were very fun and amazing teachers. Sometimes the material was presented a little vaguely, especially towards the beginning of the course, but it is usually very interesting. One weakness is that class often went over time which was a little frustrating. Another thing is that sometimes the assignments are about reading/material we have not discussed in class, which led me to make mistakes in my assignments. The assignments were sometimes a little long, but they were mostly quite fun. Sometimes I felt we were going over the same material multiple times, which was good because sometimes the material was a little complicated, but could be superfluous.

I think that the course was very well structured and I liked that there were a lot of opportunities to be graded. This made it less stressful if you had one or two hiccups during the semester... especially during this one.

narratives.question_text:
Would you recommend this course to another student? Please explain.
(Your anonymous response to this question may be viewed by Yale College students, faculty, and advisers to aid in course selection and evaluating teaching.)
comments: Absolutely! This is one of the best classes I've taken at Yale. It was a fantastic introduction to linguistics and I learned a lot.

This course is truly special and I highly advise any Yale student with a modicum of interest in linguistics to take this course. The class sessions are very open and often, one student's question will spiral into a fascinating discussion. You will get to know your classmates. The material has something for everyone. If you come from a STEM background, then you will probably like the underlying structure behind the syntactic and semantic systems and the connection to the brain. If you come from a humanities background, then you will probably like the societal impacts of language that we discuss in the course such as heritage speakers.

Definitely! Take this if you're interested in linguistics, neuroscience, cognitive science, or psychology. Or if you're just looking for an interesting class. It's not too difficult and you get out what you put into the class.
Yes! I would whole-heartily recommend this course to everyone.
I would recommend this course if you're interested in the structure of language. Be prepared for complex diagram-making and linguistic jargon.

Yes. The course is a great introduction to linguistic theory from a cognitive perspective, and we go over research and material in a very fun way. I liked the emphasis on research, especially since we were able to do research in the field on our own.
Absolutly yes! Just make sure that you know that it is not light on workload.
